mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Online copy: Images of interior plaque, exterior limestone signage and exterior blue building identifier for the Warwick Memorial Building

mods.mods:note: Address: 2300 K Street, NW. This three-story Indiana limestone building was known opened September 13th, 1954 as a division of the Hospital, and had two sections, the Warwick Memorial Cancer building and the University Cancer Research building. The building was made possible through the affiliation of the University and the Home for Foundlings, using a sum of about $400,000 left the Home under the will of Randolph T. Warwick, and was named after the donorâ€™s sisters. A grant of $200,000 from the National Cancer Institute of the U.S. Public Health Service was used to build the Research section of the structure. In 1926 The Board of Trustees discussed a Warwick bequest for founding a cancer hospital. In 1948 the Board adopted a resolution to approve the contract between the University and the Washington Home for Foundlings concerning a Warwick Cancer Clinic, and in 1950 gave approval to proceed with plans for construction of the building, for which the University donated the land. The Charles H. Tompkins Company built it. [from GW encyclopedia article]
Images taken March 15, 2012 by the staff of Special Collections.
Special Collections Research Center, The George Washington University, 2130 H Street NW, Washington, 20052, United States of America (https://library.gwu.edu/scrc/contact)
